newsitem.title: UK: Clarke accuses UK's Brown of economic cheating.
newsitem.headline: Clarke accuses UK's Brown of economic cheating.

text.p: Former finance minister Kenneth Clarke staked his claim for the leadership of Britain's Conservatives on Wednesday with a speech in which he accused his successor Gordon Brown of "economic cheating of the worst kind".
Clarke claimed Brown was preparing tax rises which he had consistently foresworn during last month's election campaign, and was now seeking a bogus justification for them.
"Labour is preparing to cook the books which we left in apple-pie order," Clarke told a meeting of Conservative lawyers in London in his first big campaign speech.

Labour swept to power in the May 1 election with a 179-seat majority. John Major immediately said he would give up the Conservative leadership, firing the starting gun for a six-candidate contest to replace him.
Clarke is the main hope of the party's centre-left, and is widely expected to come out on top of the bunch in the first round of voting among the 164 Conservative MPs on June 10.

But the absolute majority required under the rules looks beyond him and his opponents are expected to rally round a right-wing candidate, perhaps the youthful William Hague, in the second round expected a week later.
Clarke argued that the economy must become the key battleground between Labour and the Conservatives.
"Now we are in opposition, we must make Labour's almost certain inability to sustain our economic legacy the absolute centre point of the Tory attack," he said.
Chancellor of the Exchequer Brown has asked the National Audit Office, an official watchdog, to review economic forecasts made by the then Conservative government in November's budget.
"He wants to argue they are too optimistic. His motive is to try to justify tax increases now, to cover the additional Labour spending he was planning anyway," Clarke said.
"Any idea that, given the right policies, we could not sustain a growth rate averaging 2.5 percent for the rest of this decade is absurd," he added.
"Mr Brown wants to revise down that prediction simply to justify a tax increase much bigger than he led the people to expect."
Clarke said if growth did fall, it would be because Labour increased taxes, made interest rate rises more likely by allowing the Bank of England to set rates and introduced a national minimum wage.

Bookmakers Ladbrokes on Wednesday made 36-year-old ex-Welsh Secretary Hague 4/5 favourite to replace Major, but reported a flood of bets on Clarke, narrowing his odds to 6/4 from 5/2. Only a few weeks ago he was a rank outsider at 7/1.
